title: 113_s1081
content: The Act titled "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" expands and enhances authorities related to protected communications of members of the armed forces and prohibits retaliatory actions. The "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" expands prohibited retaliatory personnel actions under section 1034 of title 10, United States Code, to include representatives of Members of Congress and court proceedings. The "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" expands prohibited retaliatory personnel actions to include participating in investigations or proceedings related to communication under subparagraph (A) or (B), or assisting in actions brought under this section. The "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" broadens the scope of prohibited retaliatory actions to include violations of laws, rules, or regulations related to sexual misconduct, harassment, and discrimination. Inspector General investigations are also amended to address these issues. The "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" expands protections for whistleblowers by specifying that certain communications shall not be excluded from protection, regardless of various circumstances such as motive, method of communication, or timing. The "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" includes amendments such as inserting consent requirements and changing timeframes in certain paragraphs. Additionally, investigations by the Inspector General now cover additional subsections, and reporting requirements have been modified. The "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" has been amended to change references from the Secretary of Defense to the Secretary of the military department concerned. Reporting requirements have also been updated to include explicit determinations on prohibited personnel actions and recommendations for complaint disposition. The "Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013" has been amended to include new subsections for corrective actions in case of violations reported by the Inspector General. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the relevant military department must order necessary actions to correct prohibited personnel actions within 30 days of receiving the Inspector General's report. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the relevant military department must take disciplinary action against individuals for prohibited personnel actions as per the recommendations in the Inspector General's report. If corrective or disciplinary action is deemed inappropriate, the Secretary must provide a notice of determination or refer the report for further review within 30 days. The subsection (g) of the section is amended to require the review of complaints and provision of necessary information by the board. The subsection (g) of the section is amended to require the review of complaints and provision of necessary information by the board. Additionally, amendments are made to subsections (h) and (i) regarding burdens of proof in investigations conducted by Inspector Generals and reviews by relevant authorities. The amendments made by this section will be effective 30 days after the enactment of the Act and will apply to allegations under section 1034 of title 10, United States Code, submitted after that date.
